2390/A0/04/001/006.status_value: DRR is incorporated in primary school within the "Exploring the world"  ¿Literary Reading¿  ¿Self Cognition¿  ¿Art Work¿  ¿Physical Culture and Health¿ and ¿Mathematics¿ subjects  in secondary school within the ¿Physical Culture¿ lessons  ¿Natural science¿  ¿Kazakhstan in global world¿  ¿Human and society¿  ¿Basic safety¿  in 10-11 grades in the ¿Basic Military Training¿.

2390/A0/04/001/006.indicator_name: Child well-being monitoring system is in place. Policies developed translate to programmatic action plans but are poorly implemented including lack of M&E framework
# of policy documents address multi-sectoral approach to child well-being. Current policy environment is centred towards sectoral response especially in social work and welfare services.

Cleary defined cross-sectoral mechanism to address the needs of children and their families  especially living in difficult life circumstances is in place (y/n). Lack of inter-sectoral coordination on child's rights issues including civil society and corporate sector
# of children participating in decision-making processes in Child-friendly cities. Low engagement of children in decision-making affecting their rights
Child well-being monitoring system is in place. Policies developed translate to programmatic action plans but are poorly implemented including lack of M&E framework

Proportion of monthly cash transfers to cover for all children's basic needs vs subsistence minimum. (The monthly transfer is lower than the subsistence minimum and not sufficient to cover for all children's basic needs)

Cleary defined coordination mechanism for address needs of vulnerable families with children in place. (MoLSP is the lead agency in social policy development however requires more improved coordination with other government agencies)

Information mechanism on social assistance for vulnerable families with children in place. (Current information on existing social services is not customer oriented  thus  limited reach of vulnerable population)

Proportion of value of received social assistance by vulnerable family vs. costs related to receiving of this assistance. (Social allowances are very low  targeted social assistance cover a small proportion of population  high transportation costs)

2390/A0/04/001/006.status_value: The Government and UNICEF have agreed and tested  for baseline setting  100 key child well-being  indicators disaggregated by age  sex and location
2390/A0/04/001/006.indicator_name: Age and sex disaggregated national household survey data covering at least 70% of set key child wellbeing indicators available to policy makers
2390/A0/04/001/006.baseline_value: Household survey data covers 20% of key child wellbeing indicators

2390/A0/04/001/006.status_value: In total 20 major cities of 6 oblast (37.5%) in Kazakhstan joined Child friendly city initiative to date. The cities piloted an accreditation model with initial results discussed at the IV Forum of Kazakhstan child friendly ci ties.

Share of GDP allocated to social sectors

% of vulnerable families with children have access to complex state assistance. (Due to stigma towards vulnerable groups within communities social assistance to children is mainly provided via cash assistance only  community based social support services are still at the initial stage of development)

Child well-being monitoring system in place. (Policies developed translate to programmatic action plans but are poorly implemented including lack of M&E although they are implementing Result Based Budgeting)
# of policy documents address multi-sectoral approach to social protection. (Current policy environment is cantered towards sectoral response especially in social work and welfare services)

Common understanding of CSR concept by all stakeholders

2390/A0/04/002/005.status_value: 79% of children in 18 Centres of adaptation of children were reunited with their families.    16 253 children and persons with disabilities were covered by home-based specialized social services in 2012 (no disaggregation by adults and children  2013 data will be available in February 2014)  3 003 children with disabilities were provided special social services in institutions  day-care and rehabilitation centres in 2012  200 families were covered by the child abandonment prevention programmes i
2390/A0/04/002/005.indicator_name: % of families at risk of child abandonment   and children without parental care  with access to an essential package of preventive and protective social services  including family support  out-of-home care and alternatives to institutionalisation
# of communities supporting risk groups and disability programmes.(Negative attitude and stigma to families/children at risk or with disabilities  victims of violence and in contact with the law)

% of social standards made compliant to international norms. (Some services fail to provide quality care  services for children in contact with the law are not developed and have no standard  standards are generic and require operating instructions. Classification of disability is different from WHO classification of functional disability. Identification of violence and referral need to be set up in line with international practices)

# of introduced amendments aligning the national legal system with the international child protection standards. (Law on specialized social services is not fully implemented at the local level due to finance  lack of understanding/misinterpretation in qualification of families for services and benefits  monitoring system and operating instructions. Legislation on children with disabilities does not fully comply with the UN Convention on Persons with Disabilities.New Criminal and Criminal procedu

# of NGOs receiving social grants for the delivery of specialized social services.(Local level budget does not fully address the community needs in social services and has short utilization period. Budget allocated to institutions cannot be re-allocated to alternative care and inclusive services)
# of cases processed by the new integrated system. (Weak inter-agency coordination on children in contact with the law and children with multiple needs)
# of social workers consulting children. (Number of qualified social workers is limited at local level. Low profile of social work and weak quality of training)
# of children interviewed by the Ombudsman's Office about violations of their rights. (Lack of access of children to the Human Rights Ombudsman)

# of children in foster families (including 0-3 age and with special needs). (foster care  for children 0-3 age and with special needs is not developed and budgeted  Families upbringing children with disabilities with the access to services has no right to receive benefits and prefer institutionalisation)
# of communities with special inclusive programs. (Low esteem of families and  children at risk and children with disabilities and stigma from the local communities)

# of local authorities continue the model programmes and sustain continuum of care (Republican/UNICEF programmes may have no extension if not supported by the local budgets. Continuum of care is a new concept)

2390/A0/04/002/004.indicator_name: % of eligible infants who receive with early HIV diagnosing using DBS (dry blood spots) before the age of 2 months.

Lack of dry blood spots for early HIV diagnosing of infants. HIV exposed infants are rarely tested before 2 months and with high rates of undetermined cases. Blood sampling in use (full vein blood) is harmful for infants.

2390/A0/04/002/006.status_value: Existing legal and normative framework are reviewed from the point of international standards of youth policy and best practices. 2390/A0/04/002/006.status_value: Practices and approaches proven as highly effective in prevention suicidal behaviour of children and adolescents and promote mental health of children in conflict with law are proposed based on the outcomes of UNICEF-supported studies. 2390/A0/05/883/001.headline: In 2016  a framework for engaging in horizontal cooperation (HC) activities was established and initial engagement of partners on horizontal cooperation is underway.
2390/A0/05/883/001.baseline_value: Platforms for knowledge exchange are not established

2390/A0/05/883/001.indicator_name: Number of certified models  lessons learned and good practices in programme focus areas ready for sharing beyond Kazakhstans borders
2390/A0/05/883/001.headline: In 2016  a framework for engaging in horizontal cooperation (HC) activities was established and initial engagement of partners on horizontal cooperation is underway.

2390/A0/05/883/003.indicator_name: Availability of comprehensive  up-to-date and integrated data on the status of childrens rights (child wellbeing) at district and central levels  level of accessibility of data (by sex  age  and disability status)
2390/A0/05/883/003.headline: Kazakhstan's 3rd national MICS was concluded in 2016. The Ministry of National Economy committed to produce annual statistical compendium on children in Kazakhstan. The process for establishing a central monitoring system over child wellbeing was endorsed by authorities in Kyzylorda and Mangystau.
2390/A0/05/883/003.baseline_value: Data collection systems  including the range  scope and level of disaggregation on children are not sufficient to enable effective monitoring and evaluation of the general situation on children  the availability of data between ministries at central and local level for child-friendly policy formulation  implementation and monitoring needs improvement (CRC  2015)

2390/A0/05/883/003.indicator_name: Degree of alignment of priority* social sector indicators for Childrens Rights with international standards  * Areas of priority include: Child Poverty  Child Protection and Child Care  Justice for Children  Violence against Children  Child with Disability and Mental Health
2390/A0/05/883/003.headline: Kazakhstan's 3rd national MICS was concluded in 2016. The Ministry of National Economy committed to produce annual statistical compendium on children in Kazakhstan. The process for establishing a central monitoring system over child wellbeing was endorsed by authorities in Kyzylorda and Mangystau.
2390/A0/05/883/003.baseline_value: Indicators are not fully aligned with international standards

2390/A0/05/883/003.baseline_value: Pilot for a Child Wellbeing monitoring system is underway at oblast level

2390/A0/05/881/003.indicator_name: Readiness for national scale-up of a costed and evaluated universal progressive model of comprehensive Patronage Nursing Services which meets international standards
2390/A0/05/881/003.headline: Universal-progressive home-visiting services provide social and health assistance to vulnerable children under-5  their families and to pregnant women in Kyzylorda. The most vulnerable are prioritised to receive home-visits.

2390/A0/05/881/003.baseline_value: Visiting statistics not currently available  measurement of the quality of PNV service under piloting

2390/A0/05/881/002.indicator_name: Availability of protocols of cooperation  (including responsibilities) between the health  education  social protection sectors for the provision of integrated services for vulnerable children  protocols are incorporated into the Law on Specialised Social Services and are aligned with internationally accepted standards

2390/A0/04/007/002.status_value: Under cooperation with the National Education Academy DRR/resilience aspects were integrated in the key school children's competencies in the 12-year education standards. As Nazarbayev Intellectual Schools has joined the process of 12-year education development UNICEF invited them to participate in the National Child-centered DRR conference briefed them DRR/resilience concept and ways of its integration in education.
2390/A0/04/007/002.indicator_name: # of amendments or new curriculum or education legislative  policy or strategic documents on DRR integrated into the education system
2390/A0/04/007/002.baseline_value: DRR blocks are not part of formal curricula
